BIOS201
Notes
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.

Overview

Overview
The essential ideas of genetics and immunology will be covered in this module, which will expand on the fundamentals of genetics and genomics and how areas of study intersect. The module will emphasise the importance of genetics and genomics, encompassing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems and their importance across the disciplines of biosciences. This module will examine the diverse genome architectures, gene expression, regulation, and control, as well as how these factors relate to health and disease throughout the range of life sciences fields.

The module will also relate genomics to selected aspects of immune response, including inflammatory processes, cell signalling pathways, pathogenic responses and the importance of MHC and antigen presentation. In addition to genomic approaches, all Biosciences students will therefore gain exposure to content on the physiological bases of immune defences.

The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. It will be assessed by online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Provide a foundation for Level 5 students in key areas Bioscience studies – (a) Genetics and Genomics and (b) Immune system function.

2. Relate fundamentals of genomes and genomics to our understanding of immunology across a range of case studies from across the Biosciences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The science of genetics, including gene-editing and genome sequencing is a fast-moving and exciting area for biosciences study. In this module we will explore the fundamentals of genetics and genomics such that students can apply cutting-edge knowledge to the areas of the biosciences that interest them most. Students will be asked to consider the relevant ethical implications of current knowledge and technologies in genomics and genetics. In addition, we will expand the horizons of the module toward understanding of disease, by looking at the genomic, and physiological bases of immune defences against microbial enemies. The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. There will be plenty of opportunities for students to explore and test their understandings before they take assessments in the form of online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Outline Syllabus
Genetics & Genetics for Biosciences

This module will introduce fundamental components of genetics, genomics and immunology in a manner that will enable students to apply their comprehensions to the areas of Biosciences appropriate to their programmes.

Genomes

● Varied structures of genomes – as they relate to Biosciences programmes (including prokaryotes vs eukaryotes), including example applications of genomic knowledge across these areas
● Uses of sequenced, annotated genome maps – Applications of genome maps across the Biosciences

Genome replication & Genome Editing

We will cover DNA replication in genomes, including genetic recombination & DNA repair: We will cover replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. This part of the module will include the processes that lead to genetic variation, and its consequences for cellular, tissue and organismal functioning.

All students will learn about applications e.g. in technologies biotech/ applications/plasmids, Crispr Cas 9 for gene editing

Genome expression

Students will learn the fundamentals of Transcription & Translation (regulation, turning genes on and off, chromatin). They will cover
fundamental principles of gene regulation, including the specific ways of controlling genes e.g. action on RNA polymerase.

In consolidating and applying these concepts, we will focus on Genotype-Phenotype relationships including applications to disease examples in humans and other animals.

Immunological responses to pathogens

Students will learn about the relevance of genomics to the understanding of immune defence

In addition, we will cover selected, fundamental components of:
● Cytokine responses – including control of inflammatory processes
● Cell signalling – Immunological pathways, B cell maturation, memory cells
● MHC & Antigen presentation – significance in relation to T cells, structure, diversity
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be upwards of 600 students on this module, and we will design our teaching so that we can work at scale, but provide individuals with learning resources with which they can explore and test their learnings.

Each theme in the Syllabus will begin with a primer video from the academics in charge; these primers will outline (1) the major genetic or immunological phenomena to be explored and (2) the relevance to the broad range of Biosciences subjects.

Follow-up, in class teaching will use a blend of traditional lectures, alongside problem-based workshops, and we will hold regular online review/revision sessions, which will be voluntary for students.

We have a very broad base of students on the module – from all UG Biosciences programmes, and – with the help of academics from across Faculty our teaching team will provide supplementary materials to show the significance of the fundamentals to their chosen field of interest. Supplementary materials will include readings, videos and other media, and the ability to relate the fundamentals of genetics and immunology across Biosciences.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies, and checked proactively with Ally or a similar accessibility checker. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessment students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment Strategies

Formative Assessment and Self-evaluation

There will be frequent opportunities to test and develop knowledge, using variety of self-evaluation tools including, within-class polls; between class self-evaluation tests on Canvas (students must meet thresholds in prior tests before moving onward to further tests). Canvas tests will provide formative experience of summative assessments.

There will be two summative assessment points; mid and end of Semester.

Mid-Semester assessment will be by online, Canvas Quiz.

End of Semester will be an invigilated exam.

In both cases, the formative self-evaluation opportunities will give the students opportunities to develop confidence in their knowledge in readiness to apply it in summative assessment contexts.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning.
The online tests requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Reassessment strategy

Reassessment of C/W will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ: If LO1 is addressed in the first sit, LO2 will be addressed in the resit. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Evaluate how the fundamental properties and processes of genomes and genetics are applied across the Biosciences.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO2 Apply knowledge of DNA replication to new technologies, such as gene editing, and show evidence of ethical reasoning in relation to outcomes of these technologies.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO3 Describe and evaluate processes at the molecular level (e.g. recombination, mutation, gene expression) that cause phenotypic variation, paying attention to the consequences of variation for individuals.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO4 Evaluate how animals (including humans) defend themselves from pathogenic threats via selected components of immune responses, including inflammation and adaptive immunity.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1

Modification of this module is complete.

Version Description:
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.
Notified Biosciences Curriculum Board
Changed Status to      Modification Approval
Reassigned to Biosciences Curriculum Board and Quality Team
Changed Significant Modification to No
Marked the module as approved
The module has been approved.

Notes
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.

Overview

Overview
The essential ideas of genetics and immunology will be covered in this module, which will expand on the fundamentals of genetics and genomics and how areas of study intersect. The module will emphasise the importance of genetics and genomics, encompassing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems and their importance across the disciplines of biosciences. This module will examine the diverse genome architectures, gene expression, regulation, and control, as well as how these factors relate to health and disease throughout the range of life sciences fields.

The module will also relate genomics to selected aspects of immune response, including inflammatory processes, cell signalling pathways, pathogenic responses and the importance of MHC and antigen presentation. In addition to genomic approaches, all Biosciences students will therefore gain exposure to content on the physiological bases of immune defences.

The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. It will be assessed by online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Provide a foundation for Level 5 students in key areas Bioscience studies – (a) Genetics and Genomics and (b) Immune system function.

2. Relate fundamentals of genomes and genomics to our understanding of immunology across a range of case studies from across the Biosciences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The science of genetics, including gene-editing and genome sequencing is a fast-moving and exciting area for biosciences study. In this module we will explore the fundamentals of genetics and genomics such that students can apply cutting-edge knowledge to the areas of the biosciences that interest them most. Students will be asked to consider the relevant ethical implications of current knowledge and technologies in genomics and genetics. In addition, we will expand the horizons of the module toward understanding of disease, by looking at the genomic, and physiological bases of immune defences against microbial enemies. The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. There will be plenty of opportunities for students to explore and test their understandings before they take assessments in the form of online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Outline Syllabus
Genetics & Genetics for Biosciences

This module will introduce fundamental components of genetics, genomics and immunology in a manner that will enable students to apply their comprehensions to the areas of Biosciences appropriate to their programmes.

Genomes

● Varied structures of genomes – as they relate to Biosciences programmes (including prokaryotes vs eukaryotes), including example applications of genomic knowledge across these areas
● Uses of sequenced, annotated genome maps – Applications of genome maps across the Biosciences

Genome replication & Genome Editing

We will cover DNA replication in genomes, including genetic recombination & DNA repair: We will cover replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. This part of the module will include the processes that lead to genetic variation, and its consequences for cellular, tissue and organismal functioning.

All students will learn about applications e.g. in technologies biotech/ applications/plasmids, Crispr Cas 9 for gene editing

Genome expression

Students will learn the fundamentals of Transcription & Translation (regulation, turning genes on and off, chromatin). They will cover
fundamental principles of gene regulation, including the specific ways of controlling genes e.g. action on RNA polymerase.

In consolidating and applying these concepts, we will focus on Genotype-Phenotype relationships including applications to disease examples in humans and other animals.

Immunological responses to pathogens

Students will learn about the relevance of genomics to the understanding of immune defence

In addition, we will cover selected, fundamental components of:
● Cytokine responses – including control of inflammatory processes
● Cell signalling – Immunological pathways, B cell maturation, memory cells
● MHC & Antigen presentation – significance in relation to T cells, structure, diversity
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be upwards of 600 students on this module, and we will design our teaching so that we can work at scale, but provide individuals with learning resources with which they can explore and test their learnings.

Each theme in the Syllabus will begin with a primer video from the academics in charge; these primers will outline (1) the major genetic or immunological phenomena to be explored and (2) the relevance to the broad range of Biosciences subjects.

Follow-up, in class teaching will use a blend of traditional lectures, alongside problem-based workshops, and we will hold regular online review/revision sessions, which will be voluntary for students.

We have a very broad base of students on the module – from all UG Biosciences programmes, and – with the help of academics from across Faculty our teaching team will provide supplementary materials to show the significance of the fundamentals to their chosen field of interest. Supplementary materials will include readings, videos and other media, and the ability to relate the fundamentals of genetics and immunology across Biosciences.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies, and checked proactively with Ally or a similar accessibility checker. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessment students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment Strategies

Formative Assessment and Self-evaluation

There will be frequent opportunities to test and develop knowledge, using variety of self-evaluation tools including, within-class polls; between class self-evaluation tests on Canvas (students must meet thresholds in prior tests before moving onward to further tests). Canvas tests will provide formative experience of summative assessments.

There will be two summative assessment points; mid and end of Semester.

Mid-Semester assessment will be by online, Canvas Quiz.

End of Semester will be an invigilated exam.

In both cases, the formative self-evaluation opportunities will give the students opportunities to develop confidence in their knowledge in readiness to apply it in summative assessment contexts.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning.
The online tests requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Reassessment strategy

Reassessment of C/W will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ: If LO1 is addressed in the first sit, LO2 will be addressed in the resit. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Version Description:
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.

Notes
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.

Overview

Overview
The essential ideas of genetics and immunology will be covered in this module, which will expand on the fundamentals of genetics and genomics and how areas of study intersect. The module will emphasise the importance of genetics and genomics, encompassing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems and their importance across the disciplines of biosciences. This module will examine the diverse genome architectures, gene expression, regulation, and control, as well as how these factors relate to health and disease throughout the range of life sciences fields.

The module will also relate genomics to selected aspects of immune response, including inflammatory processes, cell signalling pathways, pathogenic responses and the importance of MHC and antigen presentation. In addition to genomic approaches, all Biosciences students will therefore gain exposure to content on the physiological bases of immune defences.

The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. It will be assessed by online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Provide a foundation for Level 5 students in key areas Bioscience studies – (a) Genetics and Genomics and (b) Immune system function.

2. Relate fundamentals of genomes and genomics to our understanding of immunology across a range of case studies from across the Biosciences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The science of genetics, including gene-editing and genome sequencing is a fast-moving and exciting area for biosciences study. In this module we will explore the fundamentals of genetics and genomics such that students can apply cutting-edge knowledge to the areas of the biosciences that interest them most. Students will be asked to consider the relevant ethical implications of current knowledge and technologies in genomics and genetics. In addition, we will expand the horizons of the module toward understanding of disease, by looking at the genomic, and physiological bases of immune defences against microbial enemies. The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. There will be plenty of opportunities for students to explore and test their understandings before they take assessments in the form of online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Outline Syllabus
Genetics & Genetics for Biosciences

This module will introduce fundamental components of genetics, genomics and immunology in a manner that will enable students to apply their comprehensions to the areas of Biosciences appropriate to their programmes.

Genomes

● Varied structures of genomes – as they relate to Biosciences programmes (including prokaryotes vs eukaryotes), including example applications of genomic knowledge across these areas
● Uses of sequenced, annotated genome maps – Applications of genome maps across the Biosciences

Genome replication & Genome Editing

We will cover DNA replication in genomes, including genetic recombination & DNA repair: We will cover replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. This part of the module will include the processes that lead to genetic variation, and its consequences for cellular, tissue and organismal functioning.

All students will learn about applications e.g. in technologies biotech/ applications/plasmids, Crispr Cas 9 for gene editing

Genome expression

Students will learn the fundamentals of Transcription & Translation (regulation, turning genes on and off, chromatin). They will cover
fundamental principles of gene regulation, including the specific ways of controlling genes e.g. action on RNA polymerase.

In consolidating and applying these concepts, we will focus on Genotype-Phenotype relationships including applications to disease examples in humans and other animals.

Immunological responses to pathogens

Students will learn about the relevance of genomics to the understanding of immune defence

In addition, we will cover selected, fundamental components of:
● Cytokine responses – including control of inflammatory processes
● Cell signalling – Immunological pathways, B cell maturation, memory cells
● MHC & Antigen presentation – significance in relation to T cells, structure, diversity
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be upwards of 600 students on this module, and we will design our teaching so that we can work at scale, but provide individuals with learning resources with which they can explore and test their learnings.

Each theme in the Syllabus will begin with a primer video from the academics in charge; these primers will outline (1) the major genetic or immunological phenomena to be explored and (2) the relevance to the broad range of Biosciences subjects.

Follow-up, in class teaching will use a blend of traditional lectures, alongside problem-based workshops, and we will hold regular online review/revision sessions, which will be voluntary for students.

We have a very broad base of students on the module – from all UG Biosciences programmes, and – with the help of academics from across Faculty our teaching team will provide supplementary materials to show the significance of the fundamentals to their chosen field of interest. Supplementary materials will include readings, videos and other media, and the ability to relate the fundamentals of genetics and immunology across Biosciences.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies, and checked proactively with Ally or a similar accessibility checker. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessment students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment Strategies

Formative Assessment and Self-evaluation

There will be frequent opportunities to test and develop knowledge, using variety of self-evaluation tools including, within-class polls; between class self-evaluation tests on Canvas (students must meet thresholds in prior tests before moving onward to further tests). Canvas tests will provide formative experience of summative assessments.

There will be two summative assessment points; mid and end of Semester.

Mid-Semester assessment will be by online, Canvas Quiz.

End of Semester will be an invigilated exam.

In both cases, the formative self-evaluation opportunities will give the students opportunities to develop confidence in their knowledge in readiness to apply it in summative assessment contexts.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning.
The online tests requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Reassessment strategy

Reassessment of C/W will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ: If LO1 is addressed in the first sit, LO2 will be addressed in the resit. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Evaluate how the fundamental properties and processes of genomes and genetics are applied across the Biosciences.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO2 Apply knowledge of DNA replication to new technologies, such as gene editing, and show evidence of ethical reasoning in relation to outcomes of these technologies.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO3 Describe and evaluate processes at the molecular level (e.g. recombination, mutation, gene expression) that cause phenotypic variation, paying attention to the consequences of variation for individuals.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO4 Evaluate how animals (including humans) defend themselves from pathogenic threats via selected components of immune responses, including inflammation and adaptive immunity.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1

Skills

Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 S2 Apply reflection to promote growth in knowledge-base, via reflection on results from diagnostic formative online tests

Changed Overview
Changed Marketing Module Synopsis
Submitted the module for approval
Modification of this module is complete.

Version Description:
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.
Notified Biosciences Curriculum Board
Changed Status to      Modification Approval
Reassigned to Biosciences Curriculum Board and Quality Team
Changed Significant Modification to No
Marked the module as approved
The module has been approved.

Version Description:
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.

Notes
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.

Overview

Overview
The essential ideas of genetics and immunology will be covered in this module, which will expand on the fundamentals of genetics and genomics and how areas of study intersect. The module will emphasise the importance of genetics and genomics, encompassing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems and their importance across the disciplines of biosciences. This module will examine the diverse genome architectures, gene expression, regulation, and control, as well as how these factors relate to health and disease throughout the range of life sciences fields.

The module will also relate genomics to selected aspects of immune response, including inflammatory processes, cell signalling pathways, pathogenic responses and the importance of MHC and antigen presentation. In addition to genomic approaches, all Biosciences students will therefore gain exposure to content on the physiological bases of immune defences.

The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. It will be assessed by online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Provide a foundation for Level 5 students in key areas Bioscience studies – (a) Genetics and Genomics and (b) Immune system function.

2. Relate fundamentals of genomes and genomics to our understanding of immunology across a range of case studies from across the Biosciences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The science of genetics, including gene-editing and genome sequencing is a fast-moving and exciting area for biosciences study. In this module we will explore the fundamentals of genetics and genomics such that students can apply cutting-edge knowledge to the areas of the biosciences that interest them most. Students will be asked to consider the relevant ethical implications of current knowledge and technologies in genomics and genetics. In addition, we will expand the horizons of the module toward understanding of disease, by looking at the genomic, and physiological bases of immune defences against microbial enemies. The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. There will be plenty of opportunities for students to explore and test their understandings before they take assessments in the form of online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Outline Syllabus
Genetics & Genetics for Biosciences

This module will introduce fundamental components of genetics, genomics and immunology in a manner that will enable students to apply their comprehensions to the areas of Biosciences appropriate to their programmes.

Genomes

● Varied structures of genomes – as they relate to Biosciences programmes (including prokaryotes vs eukaryotes), including example applications of genomic knowledge across these areas
● Uses of sequenced, annotated genome maps – Applications of genome maps across the Biosciences

Genome replication & Genome Editing

We will cover DNA replication in genomes, including genetic recombination & DNA repair: We will cover replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. This part of the module will include the processes that lead to genetic variation, and its consequences for cellular, tissue and organismal functioning.

All students will learn about applications e.g. in technologies biotech/ applications/plasmids, Crispr Cas 9 for gene editing

Genome expression

Students will learn the fundamentals of Transcription & Translation (regulation, turning genes on and off, chromatin). They will cover
fundamental principles of gene regulation, including the specific ways of controlling genes e.g. action on RNA polymerase.

In consolidating and applying these concepts, we will focus on Genotype-Phenotype relationships including applications to disease examples in humans and other animals.

Immunological responses to pathogens

Students will learn about the relevance of genomics to the understanding of immune defence

In addition, we will cover selected, fundamental components of:
● Cytokine responses – including control of inflammatory processes
● Cell signalling – Immunological pathways, B cell maturation, memory cells
● MHC & Antigen presentation – significance in relation to T cells, structure, diversity
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be upwards of 600 students on this module, and we will design our teaching so that we can work at scale, but provide individuals with learning resources with which they can explore and test their learnings.

Each theme in the Syllabus will begin with a primer video from the academics in charge; these primers will outline (1) the major genetic or immunological phenomena to be explored and (2) the relevance to the broad range of Biosciences subjects.

Follow-up, in class teaching will use a blend of traditional lectures, alongside problem-based workshops, and we will hold regular online review/revision sessions, which will be voluntary for students.

We have a very broad base of students on the module – from all UG Biosciences programmes, and – with the help of academics from across Faculty our teaching team will provide supplementary materials to show the significance of the fundamentals to their chosen field of interest. Supplementary materials will include readings, videos and other media, and the ability to relate the fundamentals of genetics and immunology across Biosciences.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies, and checked proactively with Ally or a similar accessibility checker. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessment students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment Strategies

Formative Assessment and Self-evaluation

There will be frequent opportunities to test and develop knowledge, using variety of self-evaluation tools including, within-class polls; between class self-evaluation tests on Canvas (students must meet thresholds in prior tests before moving onward to further tests). Canvas tests will provide formative experience of summative assessments.

There will be two summative assessment points; mid and end of Semester.

Mid-Semester assessment will be by online, Canvas Quiz.

End of Semester will be an invigilated exam.

In both cases, the formative self-evaluation opportunities will give the students opportunities to develop confidence in their knowledge in readiness to apply it in summative assessment contexts.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning.
The online tests requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Reassessment strategy

Reassessment of C/W will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ: If LO1 is addressed in the first sit, LO2 will be addressed in the resit. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Evaluate how the fundamental properties and processes of genomes and genetics are applied across the Biosciences.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1

Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO3 Describe and evaluate processes at the molecular level (e.g. recombination, mutation, gene expression) that cause phenotypic variation, paying attention to the consequences of variation for individuals.
Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 LO4 Evaluate how animals (including humans) defend themselves from pathogenic threats via selected components of immune responses, including inflammation and adaptive immunity.

Modification of this module is complete.

Version Description:
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.
Notified Biosciences Curriculum Board

Reassigned to Biosciences Curriculum Board and Quality Team

Notes
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.

Overview

Overview
The essential ideas of genetics and immunology will be covered in this module, which will expand on the fundamentals of genetics and genomics and how areas of study intersect. The module will emphasise the importance of genetics and genomics, encompassing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems and their importance across the disciplines of biosciences. This module will examine the diverse genome architectures, gene expression, regulation, and control, as well as how these factors relate to health and disease throughout the range of life sciences fields.

The module will also relate genomics to selected aspects of immune response, including inflammatory processes, cell signalling pathways, pathogenic responses and the importance of MHC and antigen presentation. In addition to genomic approaches, all Biosciences students will therefore gain exposure to content on the physiological bases of immune defences.

The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. It will be assessed by online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Provide a foundation for Level 5 students in key areas Bioscience studies – (a) Genetics and Genomics and (b) Immune system function.

2. Relate fundamentals of genomes and genomics to our understanding of immunology across a range of case studies from across the Biosciences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The science of genetics, including gene-editing and genome sequencing is a fast-moving and exciting area for biosciences study. In this module we will explore the fundamentals of genetics and genomics such that students can apply cutting-edge knowledge to the areas of the biosciences that interest them most. Students will be asked to consider the relevant ethical implications of current knowledge and technologies in genomics and genetics. In addition, we will expand the horizons of the module toward understanding of disease, by looking at the genomic, and physiological bases of immune defences against microbial enemies. The module is taught via a set of lectures and workshops in which students explore and develop their comprehensions. There will be plenty of opportunities for students to explore and test their understandings before they take assessments in the form of online quizzes and an unseen exam.
Outline Syllabus
Genetics & Genetics for Biosciences

This module will introduce fundamental components of genetics, genomics and immunology in a manner that will enable students to apply their comprehensions to the areas of Biosciences appropriate to their programmes.

Genomes

● Varied structures of genomes – as they relate to Biosciences programmes (including prokaryotes vs eukaryotes), including example applications of genomic knowledge across these areas
● Uses of sequenced, annotated genome maps – Applications of genome maps across the Biosciences

Genome replication & Genome Editing

We will cover DNA replication in genomes, including genetic recombination & DNA repair: We will cover replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. This part of the module will include the processes that lead to genetic variation, and its consequences for cellular, tissue and organismal functioning.

All students will learn about applications e.g. in technologies biotech/ applications/plasmids, Crispr Cas 9 for gene editing

Genome expression

Students will learn the fundamentals of Transcription & Translation (regulation, turning genes on and off, chromatin). They will cover
fundamental principles of gene regulation, including the specific ways of controlling genes e.g. action on RNA polymerase.

In consolidating and applying these concepts, we will focus on Genotype-Phenotype relationships including applications to disease examples in humans and other animals.

Immunological responses to pathogens

Students will learn about the relevance of genomics to the understanding of immune defence

In addition, we will cover selected, fundamental components of:
● Cytokine responses – including control of inflammatory processes
● Cell signalling – Immunological pathways, B cell maturation, memory cells
● MHC & Antigen presentation – significance in relation to T cells, structure, diversity
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be upwards of 600 students on this module, and we will design our teaching so that we can work at scale, but provide individuals with learning resources with which they can explore and test their learnings.

Each theme in the Syllabus will begin with a primer video from the academics in charge; these primers will outline (1) the major genetic or immunological phenomena to be explored and (2) the relevance to the broad range of Biosciences subjects.

Follow-up, in class teaching will use a blend of traditional lectures, alongside problem-based workshops, and we will hold regular online review/revision sessions, which will be voluntary for students.

We have a very broad base of students on the module – from all UG Biosciences programmes, and – with the help of academics from across Faculty our teaching team will provide supplementary materials to show the significance of the fundamentals to their chosen field of interest. Supplementary materials will include readings, videos and other media, and the ability to relate the fundamentals of genetics and immunology across Biosciences.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies, and checked proactively with Ally or a similar accessibility checker. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Due to the novel nature of the assessment students will receive formative feedback.

Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: Please see assessment strategy.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Workers are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Both assessments require students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: The curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Pre-recorded lecture content, and discussion between students and staff in workshops will have a global perspective and give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment Strategies

Formative Assessment and Self-evaluation

There will be frequent opportunities to test and develop knowledge, using variety of self-evaluation tools including, within-class polls; between class self-evaluation tests on Canvas (students must meet thresholds in prior tests before moving onward to further tests). Canvas tests will provide formative experience of summative assessments.

There will be two summative assessment points; mid and end of Semester.

Mid-Semester assessment will be by online, Canvas Quiz.

End of Semester will be an invigilated exam.

In both cases, the formative self-evaluation opportunities will give the students opportunities to develop confidence in their knowledge in readiness to apply it in summative assessment contexts.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning.
The online tests requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Formative assessment and feedback opportunities allow students to develop confidence in their knowledge and understanding and this provides an inclusive approach for students to meet the learning outcomes. The assessments foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Reassessment strategy

Reassessment of C/W will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ: If LO1 is addressed in the first sit, LO2 will be addressed in the resit. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Changed Overview
Changed Marketing Module Synopsis
Submitted the module for approval
Modification of this module is complete.

Version Description:
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.
Notified Biosciences Curriculum Board
Changed Status to      Modification Approval
Reassigned to Biosciences Curriculum Board and Quality Team
Changed Significant Modification to No
Marked the module as approved
The module has been approved.

Version Description:
Student numbers are going from 400-450 (at time of writing this module), up towards 600, perhaps higher in subsequent years. The teaching model that was planned can not scale to that number, so, with agreement of the Dean of School, I am revising this module. Where we had group work with portfolio construction and more innovative assessments at mid-term, we will move to a more traditional mode of presentation (remove group work) and assessments (online tests at mid-term), but care will be taken to enable individuals to find a way through the materials, via formative assessment opportunities.

Aims are now shortened to two, to reflect change in the teaching strategy

The second aim revised, to emphasise thematic linkage between genetics and immunology (and to replace some of the text which related to the teaching methodology we won't use).

L&T Methods - these have been revised to remove the group work, nontraditional approach, and now refer to opportunities for students to build their own learnings using formative assessments

Assessment Strategy - similarly is revised to indicate that the mid-semester assessment are online quizzes (previously, students would have made presentation materials to explain key parts of the module).

There is a re-mapping of LO SOs to assessments

Weightings of “hours” have had a minor modification, reflecting changes in methodologies.
Notified Systems Molecular and Integrative Biology Scrutiny Panel
Reassigned to Systems Molecular and Integrative Biology Scrutiny Panel and Quality Team
